item.title: Decoding ubiquitin chain signals in physiologic and stressed states
item.description:
Although Lys48-linked ubiquitin is the canonical signal for protein clearance by the proteasome, ‘alternative’ ubiquitin signals play critical yet poorly-characterised roles in misfolded protein clearance—especially under acute stress. Using linkage-specific ubiquitin probes and perturbation tools, we are uncovering how these additional ubiquitin signalling events maintain proteome robustness in a range of physiologic and stressed cellular contexts.

Current projects on ubiquitin signalling include:

Impact of specific ubiquitin linkages in misfolded protein clearance

  • Project Leads: Harvey Johnston; Richard Odle
  • Collaborators: Yogesh Kulathu; Helle Ulrich; Gabriele Kaminski-Schierle; Kirby Swatek

Nascent proteome quality control during dendritic cell activation

  • Project Lead: Estelle Wu
  • Co-PI: Michelle Linterman
  • Collaborators: Ed Roberts

item.title: HSP90 SEC-MS paper is online!
item.description:
Just in time for the holidays! It really did take a village, this one—thanks to all co-authors, across three (/four?) continents, for making this possible.

Thanks also to Samant Lab co-authors Estelle & Harvey for doing the experiments for the revision that got it over the line. Special congrats to Estelle—her first paper!

item.title: SP4 proteomics article online today in Analytical Chemistry
item.description:
This one really is Harvey’s story through-and-through—great job getting it over the line this summer!

Wouldn’t have been possible with a strong supporting cast: co-authors Kranthi and David from the Babraham Institute Mass Spectrometry Core Facility, and our always-positive collaborators George Biggs, Jo Kirkpatrick, and Holger Kramer, who were willing to test-drive this protocol from an early stage.

A couple of great write-ups also available to whet your appetites: one from Honor Pollard in the BI Communications Team, and another from Anjali Sarkar for GenEngNews. Thanks both!

More reading:

  • BI News: New technique recovers more hard-to-get proteins
  • GenEngNews: Proteomics Sample Prep Upgrade Captures More Proteins for Less
  • Harvey wins Best Poster Award at BSPR 2022

item.title: Harvey wins Best Poster Award at BSPR 2022
item.description:
Congrats to HarveyÂ Johnston for winning a Best Poster Award at the 2022 Annual Meeting of the British Society for Proteome Research, held in St. Anne’s College at Oxford University.

It’s been quite the week for Harvey. The poster presented his SP4 proteomics sample preparation method to the proteomics community for the first time, just a few days after the manuscript was accepted in Analytical Chemistry.

As well as disseminating the research, Harvey was also giving away eppendorfs filled with acetonitrile-washed glass beads, ready for those wishing to give SP4 a go in their next proteomics sample preps!

Harvey’s attendance at the meeting was generously funded by a Travel Grant from the Babraham Institute’s Postdoc Society. Thanks!
